Sentence 1: Below is a list of the chemistry department's standard course offerings, including CHE 1023L Science of Chemistry: Everyday Life (Lab)(1 credit).
Sentence 2: This course delves into the exploration of matter's properties through hands-on experimentation.

Sentence 1: The importance lies in meticulously recording observations, gathering data, and analyzing results through graphical analysis and calculations.
Sentence 2: This approach is intended to enhance understanding of the lecture topics rather than simply reiterating them.

Sentence 1:
Prerequisite: CHE 1023R
CHE 1023R Science of Chemistry: Everyday Life (Lecture) (2 credits)
This course explores the evolution of Dalton's atomic theory, the discovery of subatomic particles, and the development of atomic structure, all culminating in an understanding of bonding trends.
Sentence 2: This course explores a wide range of molecular structures, starting from basic hydrogen molecules and progressing to complex DNA strands.

Sentence 1: We also examine the various chemicals that we encounter in our daily lives.
Sentence 2: It is recommended to take CHE 1023L concurrently with this course.

Sentence 1: CHE 1024L Science of Chemistry: Global Issues Lab introduces students to current environmental challenges through hands-on experimentation, while also developing essential laboratory skills.
Sentence 2: This course is taken alongside CHE 1024R.

Sentence 1: In CHE 1024R Science of Chemistry: Global Issues (Lecture), students will explore current environmental challenges, including fossil fuel usage, climate change, nuclear energy, and ozone depletion.
Sentence 2: The course focuses on developing problem-solving skills and a foundational understanding of key chemical concepts.

Sentence 1: This course is paired with CHE 1024L as a corequisite.
Sentence 2:
CHE 1045H, 1046H Honors: General Chemistry I & II (Lecture & Lab) (5 credits)
This advanced chemistry course is designed for students who are pursuing a major in the sciences or are on a pre-medical, pre-dental, or pre-engineering track.

Sentence 1: It provides a comprehensive and fast-paced introduction to chemistry, emphasizing important concepts and preparing students for further study in the field.
Sentence 2: While recommended for chemistry majors and those interested in research, it is also open to non-science majors seeking a challenging and fulfilling experience in chemistry.

Sentence 1: CHE 1045R and 1046R General Chemistry I & II are comprehensive courses that delve into the foundational principles of chemistry at both the atomic and macroscopic levels.
Sentence 2: The courses include laboratory components to provide hands-on experience and reinforce theoretical concepts.

Sentence 1: The curriculum covers various fundamental topics in chemistry such as atomic structure, stoichiometry, properties of gases, liquids, and solids, thermochemistry, quantum theory, electronic structure of atoms, periodic table trends, chemical bonding, molecular orbital theory, properties of solutions, thermodynamics, acid-base and solubility equilibria, chemical kinetics, electrochemistry, and nuclear chemistry.
Sentence 2: The lab component, CHE 1047L, is a corequisite for CHE 1046R and includes experiments that align with the lecture material to deepen students' comprehension of the concepts introduced in the course.

Sentence 1: Students are introduced to a variety of skills such as transferring and manipulating substances, synthesizing and purifying inorganic compounds, utilizing absorption spectroscopy, performing titrations, conducting quantitative analysis, and studying chemical kinetics.
Sentence 2: Additionally, students enhance their scientific writing skills through the completion of several lab reports.

Sentence 1: Prerequisite: CHE 1046R.
Sentence 2:
CHE 1122C Chemical Analysis (4 credits)
This course is designed to familiarize science majors and pre-health students with the fundamental principles and practical applications of analytical chemistry in a single semester.

Sentence 1: The course starts by delving into the fundamentals of analytical chemistry, such as the analytical process, sampling techniques, sources of error, statistical analysis, and data interpretation.
Sentence 2: Additionally, students will explore various types of analytical methods, including wet chemistry, spectroscopy, chromatography, and potentiometric techniques.

Sentence 1: The classroom curriculum is designed to align closely with laboratory work, ensuring that students have a comprehensive understanding of the material through hands-on problem-solving exercises.
Sentence 2: Prior completion of CHE 1045R&L and 1046R&L is required.

Sentence 1: The Organic Chemistry Laboratory course (CHE 1215L) is designed to provide students with hands-on experience in fundamental experimental techniques used in organic chemistry.
Sentence 2: The course focuses on essential methods for separating, purifying, identifying, and synthesizing organic compounds.

Sentence 1: Students will develop their skills in scientific writing by completing multiple laboratory reports.
Sentence 2: Prior completion of CHE 1046R/H & 1047L is required.

Sentence 1: This course, CHE 1213R Organic Chemistry I & II, delves into the fascinating world of carbon chemistry.
Sentence 2: Students will study the structure, synthesis, properties, and reaction mechanisms of various organic compounds, including those of biological significance.

Sentence 1: This course requires completion of CHE 1046R/H and CHE 1047L as prerequisites, and CHE 1215L as a corequisite.
Sentence 2: CHE 1232C Medicinal Chemistry (3 credits) explores fundamental chemical and biological principles in the context of medicinal chemistry.

Sentence 1: The curriculum covers a wide range of topics related to pharmaceutical science, such as the mechanisms of drug action, methods for discovering new drugs, the relationship between chemical structure and drug activity, drug delivery methods, and the processes of drug metabolism and pharmacokinetics.
Sentence 2: In the laboratory sessions, students will have the opportunity to apply their knowledge by conducting experiments that involve modifying the chemical structure of drugs and analyzing the resulting products.

Sentence 1: They will also learn how to assess the acidity and hydrophobicity of drugs, synthesize a library of different drug compounds, and conduct experiments to test the effectiveness of these compounds as antimicrobial agents.
Sentence 2: Requirement: Prior completion of CHE 1046R/H and CHE 1047L is necessary.

Sentence 1: Requirement or can be taken alongside: Completion of CHE 1213R & 1215L is necessary.
Sentence 2: CHE 1233C explores the synthesis and characterization of both organic and inorganic compounds through advanced laboratory techniques.

Sentence 1: Students will learn how to purify and identify compounds using a variety of physical and chemical methods, including NMR spectrometry, UV-VIS and FTIR spectrophotometry, gas and high-performance liquid chromatography, and mass spectrometry.
Sentence 2: The course requires a prerequisite of CHE 1214R&1215L.

Sentence 1: Bioinformatics, a course worth 3 credits, explores the intersection of Biology and computing in the context of modern data-driven biology.
Sentence 2: The abundance of data in the field has made analysis increasingly complex and challenging.

Sentence 1: Bioinformatics has advanced significantly, providing essential tools for studying complex genetic sequencing and evolutionary changes in genes.
Sentence 2: This course aims to equip students with key bioinformatics tools critical for modern advancements in biology and medicine.

Sentence 1: The course will familiarize students with fundamental web-based tools for searching for similar sequences in proteins and nucleotides, accessing databases for protein structures and genes, and visualizing molecular structures.
Sentence 2: Additionally, students will be trained in reading and interpreting primary literature articles, writing research reports, and delivering oral presentations.

Sentence 1: Prerequisites: Completion of CHE1046R/H and either BIO1012R&L or 1012C is required.
Sentence 2: This course is also crosslisted as BIO1372C/H.

Sentence 1: In CHE 1375R Molecular Biochemistry, students will explore the biological aspects of cellular structure, metabolism, regulation, and replication through the lens of chemistry.
Sentence 2: The course will delve into topics such as the role of nucleic acids in protein synthesis and the bioenergetics of oxidative phosphorylation in cellular respiration.

Sentence 1: We will focus on important topics in modern biochemistry, such as protein-ligand interactions, DNA polymerization, and membrane transport.
Sentence 2: Students must have completed CHE 1046R/H, CHE 1047L, and BIO 1011R&L as prerequisites.

Sentence 1: CHE 1376R Principles of Biochemistry is a 3-credit course that explores the intricate relationship between biological molecules and their functions.
Sentence 2: Topics covered include enzyme kinetics, bioenergetics, metabolism, genetic information storage and transmission, as well as recombinant DNA technology.

Sentence 1: Additional selected topics such as membrane transport, hormone action, and muscle contraction are also discussed.
Sentence 2: Prerequisites for this course include completion of BIO 1012R&L and CHE 1213R&CHE1215L.

Sentence 1:
[Crosslisted as BIO 1375C]
This course, also listed as BIO 1376R, offers a hands-on exploration of biochemical substances and their properties.
Sentence 2: Students will learn experimental design and analysis through various techniques such as chromatography, electrophoresis, differential centrifugation, and enzyme assays including spectrophotometric and radioactive methods.

Sentence 1: This course, CHE 1378 Advanced Biochemistry, builds upon the foundational principles learned in CHE 1376R and BIO 1376L.
Sentence 2: Students will delve deeper into biochemistry by exploring metabolic pathways and the synthesis and metabolism of biomolecules.

Sentence 1: In order to gain a deeper understanding of the chemical processes within biological systems, students should have a strong grasp of the molecular properties of essential macromolecules such as nucleic acids, proteins, carbohydrates, and lipids.
Sentence 2: It is important for students to recognize the connection between the structure and function of these biomolecules, as well as have knowledge of enzyme catalysis and metabolic pathways.

Sentence 1: This course, CHE 1379H, provides an in-depth exploration of the role of metals in biology through both lecture and lab components.
Sentence 2:
Prerequisite: CHE 1375R Corequisite: CHE1377L
This course covers the fundamentals of coordination chemistry, explores spectroscopic techniques for analyzing metal ions and complexes in biological systems, and delves into the catalytic properties of key metalloproteins.

Sentence 1: Students must have completed CHE 1046R/H and CHE 1047L before enrolling.
Sentence 2: In CHE 1415L Physical Chemistry Laboratory, students will gain hands-on experience in measuring and calculating physical chemistry principles.

Sentence 1: Through a series of experiments, students will apply theoretical concepts to real-world scenarios and develop skills in quantitative physical measurements such as thermochemistry, chemical equilibria, kinetics, electrochemistry, spectrophotometry, and computer interfacing.
Sentence 2: This course will provide a solid foundation in the practical aspects of physical chemistry.

Sentence 1: This course focuses on applying biochemical principles to real-world systems.
Sentence 2: It is recommended to have taken or be concurrently enrolled in CHE 1415R.

Sentence 1: CHE 1415R and 1416R, Physical Chemistry I & II, offer a comprehensive exploration of the fundamental physical and mathematical principles that underlie a variety of chemical concepts.
Sentence 2: The first semester delves into topics such as chemical thermodynamics, thermochemistry, chemical equilibria, phases of matter, aqueous solutions, electrochemistry, and the kinetic molecular theory of gases.

Sentence 1: In the second semester, we delve into the intricate quantum mechanics of atoms and molecules, including the solutions to the Schrodinger equation.
Sentence 2: We also cover topics such as vibrational, rotational, and electronic spectroscopies, as well as the electronic structure of multi-electron atoms and molecules and chemical bonding.

Sentence 1: Prior coursework in CHE 1046R/H & CHE 1047L, as well as MAT 1412/1413, is required.
Sentence 2: This course, CHE 1607 Inorganic and Structural Chemistry, requires either PHY 1031/1032R&L or 1041/1042R&L as a prerequisite or corequisite.

Sentence 1: It provides students with a thorough understanding of advanced concepts in inorganic chemistry.
Sentence 2: Students will gain an understanding of how theories of chemical bonding can be applied to predict the electronic structures of compounds, and how these structures influence the chemical and physical properties that are observed.

Sentence 1: The course will focus on the transition between two-electron energies in weak ligand fields and one-electron energies in strong ligand fields, highlighting how these concepts relate to natural phenomena.
Sentence 2: Upon completion of the course, students will gain knowledge on how symmetry can be applied to forecast molecular properties, determine the stability of different metal complexes, and comprehend the interactions among light, electrons, and nuclei that contribute to various phenomena in our daily lives.

Sentence 1: Prerequisite courses include CHE 1046R/H & 1047L, MAT 1413.
Sentence 2: In CHE 1609H Bioinorganic Chemistry, students will explore essential inorganic chemistry principles such as chemical bonding, structure, reactions, and characterization methods, and learn how these concepts are applied in the fields of biology and medicine.

Sentence 1: This course offers a deep dive into the rapidly growing interdisciplinary field of bioinorganic chemistry.
Sentence 2: This course explores various topics such as metalloenzymes, iron transport proteins, biomineralization in bones and shells, and chemotherapeutic agents.

Sentence 1: Prior completion of CHE 1046R/H & 1047L is required.
Sentence 2: CHE 1611, 1611H Molecular Structure and Dynamics (3 credits) focuses on understanding the structure of molecules using molecular modeling.

Sentence 1: The course covers theoretical predictions of electronic structure and properties, structure manipulation, simulation techniques like molecular dynamics and Monte Carlo methods, and the use of popular software packages for visualization.
Sentence 2: This course utilizes a hands-on workshop approach alongside combined lectures and computer lab sessions.

Sentence 1: Prerequisites include CHE 1046R/H & 1047L.
Sentence 2: CHE 1930 Selected Topics (2 credits) is a seminar that delves into current issues and literature in chemistry, designed for senior chemistry majors and select juniors.

Sentence 1: Required components include assigned topics, scheduled conferences, and a final report.
Sentence 2: Prior approval from the instructor is necessary.

Sentence 1:
CHE 1936 Introduction to Chemical Research (0.5 credits)
This course provides students with an opportunity to explore the research interests of our faculty and gain insight into potential careers in modern chemistry.
Sentence 2: It is designed for students with limited background in chemistry or research, and aims to assist them in selecting a research mentor for their undergraduate studies, especially for those considering a major in chemistry.

Sentence 1: Students will have the unique opportunity to explore faculty research laboratories and gain hands-on experience in chemical research.
Sentence 2: Prior completion of CHE 1046R/H & 1047L is required for enrollment in this course.

Sentence 1: CHE 1937, 1938 Seminar in Advanced Chemistry offers 1 credit and consists of biweekly two-hour seminar meetings.
Sentence 2: This course covers a wide range of topics in chemistry across various fields.

Sentence 1: Prior completion of CHE 1213R & 1215L or instructor permission is required.
Sentence 2: CHE 4911, Research in Chemistry, is a course that offers 1-3 credits.

Sentence 1: Prior approval from the department is necessary, and final approval from Academic Standards is required to enroll.
Sentence 2: Additionally, there may be a laboratory fee, which will be determined on an individual basis.

Sentence 1: Yeshiva College's Department of Computer Science has established an Academic Integrity Policy that outlines guidelines for resources and collaboration on assignments.
Sentence 2: The policy specifies which sources of information can be used, the level of collaboration allowed among students, and whether incorporating someone else's work is permitted.

Sentence 1: These rules are communicated to students through assignment instructions, lecture slides, course syllabi, class emails, and online forums.
Sentence 2: It is the students' responsibility to understand and adhere to both the general rules of each course and the specific guidelines for each assignment.

Sentence 1: In cases where there is uncertainty about a particular resource, students should err on the side of caution and assume that its use is not allowed until clarification is provided by the professor.
Sentence 2: When incorporating code or other work from external sources into an assignment, students must adhere to the citation guidelines provided by their professor.

Sentence 1: If no specific citation practice is specified, students should include the URL of the code and the date it was retrieved.
Sentence 2: The code snippet below demonstrates how to sort a list of numbers in Python using the built-in sort() function.

Sentence 1:
```python
numbers = [4, 2, 7, 1, 3]
numbers.sort()
print(numbers)
```

This code creates a list of numbers, `[4, 2, 7, 1, 3]`, and then uses the `sort()` method to arrange the numbers in ascending order.
Sentence 2: The sorted list is then printed out, resulting in `[1, 2, 3, 4, 7]`.

Sentence 1:
Adapted from: https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list.sort

Sentence 2: Writing helps us to evolve as critical, analytic, and synthetic thinkers by encouraging us to actively absorb, question, and engage with the world around us.

Sentence 1: By exercising our ability to choose and manipulate language, we become more attuned to the impact that words have in various aspects of life, such as work, politics, relationships, and society.
Sentence 2: Through the exploration of language, we come to understand that words are multifaceted, able to capture a range of meanings and perspectives beyond our own.

Sentence 1: By delving into introspection and reflection, we are able to better understand not only ourselves but also those who may be different from us.
Sentence 2: As students of language, we explore the diverse spectrum of human potential and appreciate a wide array of human experiences.

Sentence 1: Through this study, we connect with and reflect upon the works of countless individuals who have captured the essence of human existence through written word over the course of history.
Sentence 2: The Writing Minor at Yeshiva College acknowledges the universal value of strong writing skills, emphasizing their importance across all disciplines and professions.

Sentence 1: By developing proficiency in writing, students are equipped to effectively communicate in their current endeavors and prepare for future opportunities, whether in higher education, professional writing roles, or any other career path they may pursue.
Sentence 2: This minor empowers students to articulate their thoughts and ideas with clarity and precision, enhancing their ability to succeed in any field.

Sentence 1:
The Creative Writing Minor aims to help students achieve the following learning goals:

- Cultivate effective and confident writing skills in creative and expository forms, with an emphasis on revision and editing.
Sentence 2: - Build a diverse set of strategies for generating ideas, writing, and revising work.

Sentence 1: - Utilize interpretive skills to enhance both reading and writing abilities.
Sentence 2: - Develop a unique voice and a strong sense of authorship.

Sentence 1: - Explore various genres and audiences, including fiction, poetry, playwriting, screenwriting, and creative nonfiction.
Sentence 2: - View writing as an art form, craft, and rhetorical tool for expressing ideas.

Sentence 1: - Find enjoyment and fulfillment in the writing process.

The thoughts of economists and political philosophers hold immense power, whether they are accurate or flawed.
Sentence 2: In reality, these ideas often govern the world more significantly than we realize.

Sentence 1: John Maynard Keynes once said that the man of the future would be skilled in statistics and economics.
Sentence 2: Oliver Wendell Holmes believed that studying economics equips individuals with the necessary analytical tools to comprehend how economies distribute limited resources to create products and services, and how various factors such as policies, technology, and institutions impact economic performance.

Sentence 1: Moreover, it equips students with a structured approach to analyzing personal, corporate, and household choices.
Sentence 2: The Basic Track within the Economics major offers valuable preparation for students pursuing careers in law, business, journalism, or public policy.

Sentence 1: The Mathematical Economics Track is designed to provide students with a strong foundation in quantitative methods that will prepare them for advanced studies in economics, such as YU's Masters in Quantitative Economics program, as well as for careers in finance and consulting.
Sentence 2: This track is a valuable complement to a variety of majors, including mathematics, other social sciences, physics, and pre-engineering.

Sentence 1: The introductory courses in microeconomics and macroeconomics are crucial for students in non-economic majors as they provide a foundational knowledge that complements a liberal arts education and opens up opportunities for a variety of elective courses.
Sentence 2: For further details about the Economics Department at Yeshiva College, please reach out to Professor James Kahn at james.kahn@yu.edu or 212-960-5400 ext.

Sentence 1:
Program Information

Courses
Explore our wide range of undergraduate courses by checking out the Schedule of Classes for the most up-to-date offerings for the current semester.
Sentence 2: ECO 1010 Principles of Economics is a 3-credit course that provides an introduction to the fundamental principles of micro- and macroeconomics.

Sentence 1: Topics covered include supply and demand, the behavior of firms and consumers, theory of comparative advantage, market dynamics, market failures, and policy issues such as taxation, regulation, and income redistribution.
Sentence 2: Additionally, the course explores concepts such as general equilibrium, business cycles, inflation, unemployment, national income accounting, monetary and fiscal policy, public debt and social insurance, international trade and exchange rates, and long-term growth.

Sentence 1: Please note that this course replaced ECO 1031 and ECO 1041 starting in the Fall 2015 semester.
Sentence 2:
Course Title: Intermediate Microeconomics (ECO 1101)
Credit Hours: 3

This course delves into the theory of elasticity, indifference curves, and their applications in economics.

Sentence 1: Students will also explore the cost of production, output markets, externalities, and input markets.
Sentence 2: Linear programming and optimization theory, using calculus, will be utilized to analyze economic models.

Sentence 1: Prerequisite: MAT 1412 (may be taken concurrently) or permission from the instructor.
Sentence 2:
Prerequisite: ECO 1010
Course Title: ECO 1170 Contemporary Microeconomic Issues
Credit Hours: 3
This course utilizes economic principles to analyze both public policy and individual decision-making processes.

Sentence 1: The course covers a range of topics that may change each term, such as uncertainty and information in economics, crime, government regulation of business, education, charity, immigration, contracts, discrimination, medical care, transportation, congestion, geographic location, and income distribution.
Sentence 2: Students must have completed ECO 1010, MAT 1412, or have the Instructor's permission to enroll.

Sentence 1: ECO 1177 Game Theory explores the development of models of rational behavior in interactive situations through the study of non-cooperative, cooperative, and evolutionary games.
Sentence 2: This course delves into the application of game theory in various fields such as international relations, economics, business, politics, psychology, philosophy, and evolutionary biology, where it is utilized to make informed decisions and strategies in situations where individuals interact to reach mutually beneficial agreements or resolve conflicts.

Sentence 1: This course, ECO 1201 Intermediate Macroeconomics, requires completion of ECO 1101 and MAT 1412 or Instructor's permission.
Sentence 2: The course covers topics such as national income accounting, national income determination models, consumption functions, investment theory, business cycle theory, stabilization policy, LM-IS-BP analysis, aggregate demand and aggregate supply analysis, as well as economic growth and development theories.

Sentence 1: Requirement: It is recommended to have completed MAT 1412 (or be taking it at the same time) or obtain permission from the instructor.
Sentence 2: It is also advisable to have taken ECO 1010 or 1101.

Sentence 1: ECO 1221 Money and Banking is a 3-credit course that explores the fundamental concepts of money and the operations of the commercial banking system.
Sentence 2: Topics covered include financial markets, institutions, hedging mechanisms, yield curves, and the role of the Federal Reserve System and other financial intermediaries.

Sentence 1: Additionally, students will learn about national income determination models, the monetarist-fiscalist debate, LM-IS-BP analysis, and the significance of money in international finance.
Sentence 2: Prerequisite for this course is ECO 1010 or permission from the instructor.

Sentence 1: ECO 1421 Econometrics is a 3-credit course that focuses on applying regression techniques to test and forecast economic trends.
Sentence 2: The course covers the development of the two-variable regression model and expands into multivariate models, functional form considerations, dummy variables, and distribution lag models.

Sentence 1: This course addresses issues related to autocorrelation, multicollinearity, heteroskedasticity, and system models.
Sentence 2: Prior knowledge in ECO 1010, 1101, or 1201 and STA 1021 is required.

Sentence 1: In ECO 1501 Public Finance, students will explore various forms of taxation including social balance, personal, and corporate income taxes, as well as sales and property taxes.
Sentence 2: The course also covers current economic theories on taxation, public debt, and expenditure analysis across different sectors such as energy, transportation, housing, education, pollution control, poverty, and quotas.

Sentence 1: Students will also learn about externalities, public goods, and public choice.
Sentence 2: Prerequisites for this course include ECO 1010, 1101, or 1201.

Sentence 1: In ECO 1701 International Economics, students will delve into the theory of international trade, international finance, commercial policy, balance of payments, the foreign exchange market, competitiveness in the global economy, international macroeconomics, and foreign direct investment.
Sentence 2: This course explores the impact of international connections on global economics, focusing on the influences of consumers, businesses, and government policies.

Sentence 1: It delves into how legal institutions and laws contribute to economic efficiency and societal objectives like justice.
Sentence 2: Prerequisite: ECO 1010, 1101, or 1201.

Sentence 1: This course covers topics such as property rights, environmental regulations, administrative procedures, contracts, and liability, as well as public utility and antitrust laws.
Sentence 2: It also explores individual rights and issues of discrimination.

Sentence 1: Students must have completed ECO 1010, 1101, or 1201 before enrolling in this course.
Sentence 2: Explore the role of labor in the American economy with ECO 2201 Labor Economics.

Sentence 1: This 3-credit course delves into the factors influencing the supply and demand for labor, the intricacies of wage determination, the impact of unionism on labor issues, and the dynamics of industrial relations.
Sentence 2: Additionally, we will examine public policy towards labor.

Sentence 1: Prerequisite: ECO 1010, 1101, or 1201.
Sentence 2: ECO 2531 Health Economics is a 3-credit course that applies economic tools and concepts to analyze the healthcare industry.

Sentence 1: Topics covered include the impact of healthcare on overall health, hospital behavior, health workforce supply, and the demand for healthcare services.
Sentence 2: The impact of demographic changes on healthcare systems and the analytical approaches used by economists to quantify the economic costs associated with death and disability.

Sentence 1: The focus is on the United States and its current state, with a comparison to other nations.
Sentence 2:
Prerequisites: ECO 1010, 1101, or 1201, or permission from the instructor
ECO 2601: Financial Economics
3 credits
This course provides a comprehensive examination of financial market theory through an economic lens.

Sentence 1: The goal is to analyze how interactions within financial markets present both opportunities and risks for individuals, extending beyond traditional uncertainties to impact economic and financial variables at a systemic level.
Sentence 2: We will be examining these phenomena through the lens of economic equilibrium, a key conceptual framework.

Sentence 1: Our exploration of finance is grounded in the principles of modern microeconomics.
Sentence 2: This course focuses on developing mathematical models to analyze the welfare properties of financial markets and their impact on asset prices.

Sentence 1: Students must have completed ECO 1101, ECO 1201, MAT 1412, or received permission from the instructor to enroll.
Sentence 2: The course ECO 2801 Auctions and Market Design, worth 3 credits, is designed to explore both classical and contemporary research in the field of market design.

Sentence 1: Divided into two main parts, the course aims to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of market theory and its practical applications.
Sentence 2: The course is divided into two main sections.

Sentence 1: The first half delves into the theory of auctions in a simplified setting, exploring both the traditional concepts and the challenges that arise in practice.
Sentence 2: It also examines the effectiveness of current strategies in addressing these challenges.

Sentence 1: The second half of the course focuses on topics related to matching.
Sentence 2: We begin by addressing the matching problem, also known as the marriage problem, and introduce the concept of stable matching.

Sentence 1: Next, we expand the idea of stability to include many-to-one and many-to-many matching scenarios involving contracts.
Sentence 2: Following an examination of the practical uses of stable matching, we evaluate it in comparison to other methods, such as top trading cycles.

Sentence 1: In our discussions, we explore various practical uses of market design such as medical residency matching, school selection, course assignment, and kidney exchange.
Sentence 2: The final classes will focus on recent advancements in market design theory, particularly in the field of matching.

Sentence 1: This course, ECO 3601 Economic Perspectives, requires prior completion of ECO 1101 and MAT 1412 or instructor approval.
Sentence 2: The topics covered in this 3-credit course are drawn from the symposium themes of the Journal of Economic Perspectives, showcasing the latest research in the field.

Sentence 1: Potential topics include fiscal policy, advanced consumption theory, regulation of financial markets, economics of organizations, electronic commerce, higher education, healthcare reform, and the debate between state and private ownership.
Sentence 2: Requirements: Completion of ECO 1011/1041, ECO 1021/1031, and ECO 1201 or 1221 is necessary.

Sentence 1: Additionally, ECO 4901 Independent Study and ECO 4911 Guided Project are available for enrollment.
Sentence 2: There is also the possibility of taking an Honors version of these courses, indicated by an H designation when offered.

Sentence 1: Students have the option to choose between a Basic or Mathematical Economics Major Track within the Economics Department.
Sentence 2: The Economics Basic Track consists of 34 credits, including required courses such as Principles of Economics, Calculus, Statistics, Intermediate Microeconomics, Intermediate Macroeconomics, and Econometrics.

Sentence 1: Students must also complete regular economics electives and advanced economics electives.
Sentence 2: On the other hand, the Mathematical Economics Track requires 36 credits, with courses in Calculus 1, Calculus 2, Multivariable Calculus, Intermediate Microeconomics, Intermediate Macroeconomics, Intro Statistics/Probability Theory, and Econometrics/Math Statistics.

Sentence 1: Regular economics electives and advanced economics electives are also part of this track.
Sentence 2: Regular economics electives are courses that do not have Intermediate Microeconomics or Intermediate Macroeconomics as prerequisites.

Sentence 1: Advanced economics electives require either Intermediate Microeconomics or Intermediate Macroeconomics as prerequisites.
Sentence 2: Students in the math track can choose between taking ECO 1010 or a Finance/Accounting class, but they are not permitted to take both.

Sentence 1: Advanced electives require a pre-requisite of either ECO 1101 or 1201.
Sentence 2:
Economics Minor Requirements:
- To complete the Economics minor, students must earn a total of 19 credits.

Sentence 1: - Required courses include ECO 1010 (Principles of Economics) worth 3 credits, and either MAT 1412 (Calculus 1) or MAT 1410 (Fundamentals of Calculus) worth 4 credits.
Sentence 2: - Students must also take 12 credits of regular Economics electives.

Sentence 1: - Note that STA 1021 can only count towards the minor if ECO 1421 is also taken.
Sentence 2: - A grade of C- or higher is required in all major or minor courses.

Sentence 2: Students in the Yeshiva College English Department are provided with a unique opportunity to explore a diverse range of cultures and time periods through their study of literature from classical Greece, medieval Europe, Victorian Britain, and contemporary U.S. and world literature.

Sentence 1: Students are encouraged to cultivate their analytical and creative skills as writers and thinkers, honing their ability to communicate effectively and persuasively.
Sentence 2: By exploring various literary forms such as poetry, fiction, nonfiction, drama, film, and digital genres, English courses broaden our understanding of the diverse and profound accomplishments of humanity, inspiring us to make our own meaningful contributions.

Sentence 1: These qualities are highly valued across many different industries.
Sentence 2: Recent articles in both mainstream media and specialized publications have highlighted the benefits of skills acquired through literature and writing courses.

Sentence 1: These skills are not only valuable in professions such as teaching, publishing, and journalism, but also in any field where critical thinking, analysis, and strong communication skills are essential.
Sentence 2: English majors from YC have pursued diverse career paths including business, medicine, law, television production, filmmaking, and urban planning.

Sentence 1: During their time at YC, English majors become part of a supportive and engaging community.
Sentence 2: Starting with their first collaboration in our introductory course, Interpreting Texts, students in our program begin a collective exploration that leads them to the Senior Colloquium.

Sentence 1: This year-long dialogue, involving both students and faculty members from the English Department, serves as the pinnacle of their academic journey.
Sentence 2: Whether you choose to major in English, minor in the subject, or pursue our Writing minor, you will have the opportunity to engage in meaningful discussions with peers and professors.

Sentence 1: Through the exploration of texts, you will not only cultivate a lifelong passion for learning but also experience moments of unexpected discovery and inspiration.
Sentence 2: For information on the mission and goals of the Writing Minor, click here.

Sentence 1: Additionally, you can find information on our new Media Studies Minor by clicking here.
Sentence 2:
Mission Statement:
The English Department is dedicated to teaching the essential forms, traditions, theories, and practices that shape modern literary studies.

Sentence 1: We aim to equip students with the skills and critical thinking abilities needed to interpret, analyze, and generate texts.
Sentence 2: Our ultimate goal is to cultivate a deep appreciation for language and literature, fostering a lifelong passion for the written word (Derek Attridge).

Sentence 1: Through mentoring readers with a wide range of cultural influences, from ancient Greece to modern-day America, our goal is to expand students' knowledge of themselves and others, fostering a greater sense of intellectual diversity.
Sentence 2: Additionally, by honing their writing skills, we aim to cultivate students' creativity and analytical abilities, empowering them to effectively communicate in today's intricate society.

Sentence 1:
Student Learning Objectives
Develop strong critical analysis skills through thoughtful reasoning
Explore diverse literary traditions and forms, while gaining insight into the evolving landscape of literature
Engage in meaningful self-reflection on personal cultural backgrounds and values, while also appreciating and respecting the cultures and values of others.
Sentence 2: To enhance your communication skills, reach out to others through both written and verbal means.

Sentence 1: For more details on the English Department at Yeshiva College, feel free to contact Professor Paula Geyh at geyh@yu.edu or 212.960-5400 ext.
Sentence 2: Students pursuing a minor in Creative Writing must complete a total of 15 credits.

Sentence 1: This includes taking five Creative Writing courses (ENG 1300-1899).
Sentence 2: It is important to note that FYWR 1020/H is a prerequisite for ENG Creative Writing courses and does not count towards the minor.

Sentence 1: In addition, students are required to take at least one literary studies course focusing on the pre-1700 period (Medieval to Early Modern Literature and Culture) and one course focusing on the period between 1700-1900.
Sentence 2: To earn an English Minor, students must complete a total of 18 credits.

Sentence 1: This includes taking ENG 2010, Interpreting Texts, as well as five additional ENG courses.
Sentence 2: Two of these courses can be from the Core ENG courses numbered 1001-1099, and one can be a Creative Writing course (ENG 1300-1899).

Sentence 1: It is important to note that FYWR 1020/H can be taken in the same semester as ENG 2010, but is a prerequisite for all other ENG courses.
Sentence 2: The Media Studies Minor consists of 18 total credits, with specific requirements for course selection.

Sentence 1: ENG 2010, "Interpreting Texts," is a mandatory course.
Sentence 2: In addition, students must complete six more ENG credits, including one Creative Writing course and one media-related course at the 2000- or 3000-level.

Sentence 1: One three-credit course from a different discipline is also required.
Sentence 2: Finally, students must choose two more approved courses, which may include Core courses.

Sentence 1: Please note that these requirements do not contribute towards the 18 credits needed for the minor.
Sentence 2: Studying history at YU is a unique experience that goes beyond simply acquiring skills or solving problems.

Sentence 1: It offers a deeper understanding of the past and how it shapes the present, providing valuable insights into the complexities of human societies and cultures.
Sentence 2: History is the shared narrative of humanity, a reflection of our past and a roadmap to understanding the present world and our own identities.

Sentence 1: Through studying history, we gain insights into the evolution of our society and ourselves.
Sentence 2: We have come to understand that events can be interpreted in numerous ways, with multiple perspectives and voices shaping the same story.

Sentence 1: Historians skillfully uncover and bring to life these diverse voices, utilizing them to craft narratives that provide insight into our past and help us make sense of our present society.
Sentence 2: While we acknowledge the existence of multiple perspectives and the absence of a definitive truth, we understand that history and myth should not be conflated.

Sentence 1: As educators, we strive to impart essential skills to our students, such as critical thinking, a thirst for knowledge, the capacity to develop well-supported arguments based on credible sources, and the confidence to effectively present and defend their ideas in any setting.
Sentence 2: Having skills in history can be beneficial in various aspects of life, not just limited to academia.

Sentence 1: Students who are proficient in history are well-suited for careers in law, public service, and any profession that demands critical thinking and a comprehensive knowledge of the world.
Sentence 2: Individuals who choose to pursue teaching careers in secondary or postgraduate education at Yeshiva University will graduate with a comprehensive understanding of core historical subjects and the necessary academic skills to succeed in advanced studies.

Sentence 1: The department is dedicated to fostering the intellectual growth of all students, regardless of their chosen major or future career path.
Sentence 2: Join us as we explore and learn from the past together.

Sentence 1: Mission Statement: The Robert Beren Department of History at Yeshiva University aims to provide students with a deep understanding of history, emphasizing its significance in shaping the present.
Sentence 2: Our courses engage students in small, interactive discussions where instructors present the multifaceted narratives of world history.

Sentence 1: Students are encouraged to analyze sources critically and draw their own conclusions.
Sentence 2: Our curriculum spans various historical topics, with a focus on the rich history of Jews and Judaism.

Sentence 1: The History curriculum covers a wide range of topics, including Roman Emperors, Renaissance and Reformation, History of the Book, US Presidents, History of Piracy, Legal History, Modern Russia, Social Movements, History of the Jerusalem Temple, the Talmudic Rabbis, Medieval Jewish History, Jews in the New World, the Jewish Experience in Europe, The Holocaust, and History of Modern Israel.
Sentence 2: By exploring these diverse subjects, students are not only gaining a solid understanding of history but also developing critical thinking skills and the ability to think independently.

Sentence 1: By engaging in writing assignments and participating in dynamic class conversations, students develop the skill of constructing compelling arguments and effectively communicating them to their classmates.
Sentence 2: Furthermore, they cultivate an understanding of the diverse and complex nature of human existence, as well as their responsibilities as active participants in society, academia, and the worldwide community.

Sentence 1: High-achieving students have the opportunity to enroll in graduate courses at the Bernard Revel Graduate School of Jewish Studies and are encouraged to explore the joint BA/MA program in Jewish Studies.
Sentence 2: The program aims to help students develop a deeper understanding of how historians collect, interpret, and analyze source material to construct a coherent narrative.

Sentence 1: Showing an understanding of the diverse range of human experiences throughout different cultures and time periods.
Sentence 2: Crafting and effectively conveying their own interpretations of history through concise and clear writing.

Sentence 1: To learn more about the General History Division, reach out to Professor Jeffrey Freedman at freedman@yu.edu.
Sentence 2: For inquiries about the Jewish History Division, please contact Professor Joshua Karlip at Karlip@yu.edu.

Sentence 1:
Program Information:
The History Major consists of thirty-three credits, including courses such as HIST 1101, 1102, and either 3001 or 3002 (capstone course), along with 24 additional HIST credits.
Sentence 2: It is required to take 6 credits in American History.

Sentence 1: Students can earn up to 12 additional credits in Jewish history beyond what is required for the Jewish studies requirement and distribution, which can be counted towards their major.
Sentence 2: Additionally, a maximum of 6 AP History credits with a score of 4 or 5 can also be applied towards the major.

Sentence 1: The History Minor requires completion of 18 credits, including HIST 1101 and HIST 1102, as well as 12 additional history credits.
Sentence 2: Of those 12 credits, at least 3 must be in American History.

Sentence 1: Additionally, students may count up to 6 credits in Jewish history towards the minor, as long as they are not already being used to fulfill the Jewish studies requirement or distribution.
Sentence 2: Students may apply up to three AP History credits with a score of 4 or 5 towards the minor.

Sentence 1:
The faculty at Beren (B) and/or Wilf (W) includes Joseph Angel, Selma Botman, and Douglas R Burgess Jr.
Enrichment can be found in a variety of fields, but the use of academic tools to deepen one's understanding of the Jewish heritage is particularly intimate and rewarding.
Sentence 2: This is why there is a significant Jewish Studies requirement in the college curriculum at YU, and why the Jewish Studies major or minor should be of serious interest to students seeking a comprehensive understanding of Judaism and the Jewish people.

Sentence 1: Students studying Jewish Studies have the opportunity to take courses in Bible, Jewish History, and Jewish Philosophy and Thought from faculty members in the Department of Bible, Hebrew, and Near Eastern Studies and the Robert M. Beren Department of History.
Sentence 2: Those majoring in Jewish Studies can specialize in one of these areas for their concentration.

Sentence 1: The Jewish Studies courses at Yeshiva College cater to two primary groups: the general student population and students majoring in Jewish Studies.
Sentence 2: The courses aim to educate all students about Jewish civilization from ancient times to the present day, fostering an understanding of the cultural and historical contexts in which Judaism has evolved.

Sentence 1: The goal for majors is to enhance their ability to analyze primary and secondary sources, conduct independent research, and ultimately prepare them for advanced studies in Jewish Studies at the graduate level.
Sentence 2: Undergraduate students who have completed core courses in specific disciplines (JHI, JTP, BIB) can apply for permission to take graduate-level courses in those areas at the Bernard Revel Graduate School of Jewish Studies.

Sentence 1: Students can earn elective credits towards fulfilling the undergraduate Jewish Studies requirement by taking the Revel course.
Sentence 2: To gain admission, students must obtain the necessary form from the Office of the Deans and have it signed by the instructor of the Revel course, the chair of the Yeshiva College Jewish Studies department, and the associate dean of Yeshiva College.

Sentence 1: In order to register for a Revel course, undergraduate students must meet specific criteria and complete the Request to Take Graduate Course for Undergraduate Credit form.
Sentence 2: This form must then be submitted to the dean of Revel for final approval.

Sentence 1: Eligible students include juniors with a 3.4 GPA or seniors with a 3.0 GPA (and a 3.2 in Jewish Studies).
Sentence 2: Yeshiva University has a rich history in mathematics, with esteemed alumni such as Michael Aizenman, Hillel Furstenberg, Charles Peskin, and Benjamin Weiss.

Sentence 1: The current Mathematical Sciences programs at the university uphold this tradition by providing top-quality education and research opportunities.
Sentence 2: The profession of mathematics involves trained individuals who use mathematical and statistical techniques to analyze data and solve real-world problems in various industries such as business, engineering, and healthcare.

Sentence 1: Mathematicians often collaborate with other professionals in teams to develop models, interpret data, make projections, and solve optimization problems.
Sentence 2: Having a strong foundation in various disciplines, such as physics, economics, computer science, or biology, can greatly enhance the application of mathematical concepts in different fields.

Sentence 1: Mathematics-related careers are poised to be some of the most lucrative and promising opportunities in the future, offering high income potential, strong growth prospects, and positive environmental impact.
Sentence 2: In recent years, there has been a rise in job opportunities for mathematicians.

Sentence 1: Graduates with a solid foundation in mathematics are in high demand across various industries and fields of study.
Sentence 2: Mathematicians are becoming essential in the technology industry, specifically in areas like artificial intelligence and machine learning, where their expertise is crucial for pushing the boundaries of innovation.

Sentence 1: The faculty members in the mathematics department are dedicated to teaching at both the undergraduate campuses and within the graduate programs at the Katz School of Science and Health, providing a strong foundation for students pursuing careers in mathematics and related fields.
Sentence 2: The research conducted by this group has garnered high acclaim, with achievements such as receiving the prestigious Humboldt Research Award and securing external funding from esteemed institutions like the National Science Foundation (NSF), National Institute of Health (NIH), National Cancer Institute (NCI), National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), Simons Foundation, and the Sloan Foundation.

Sentence 1: Additionally, many faculty members have authored research monographs and textbooks, further solidifying their reputation as leaders in their field.
Sentence 2:
Degree Programs
Bachelor of Arts in Mathematical Sciences
Specializations available in pure and applied mathematics, computational science, pre-actuarial, and financial mathematics.

Sentence 1:
Combined BA/MA Program
Requirements for admission include junior standing and a minimum GPA of 3.2.
Sentence 2: Prerequisite courses include Calculus I, II, Multivariable Calculus, and Linear Algebra with a grade of B+ or higher.

Sentence 1: Students in the BA/MA Program are allowed to take up to 12 math graduate credits that count towards both their BA and MA degrees.
Sentence 2: The MA in Mathematical Sciences and PhD in Mathematical Sciences programs prepare students for advanced degrees and careers in mathematics and related fields.

Sentence 1: Recent graduates have gone on to pursue further education at prestigious graduate schools such as Yale University, MIT, Harvard University, and others, or have found employment at top companies.
Sentence 2:
Professional Opportunities
Some of the top companies offering career opportunities include Google, Facebook, Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan Chase, American Express, Morgan Stanley, Capital One, BlackRock, Milliman, PricewaterhouseCoopers, and Accenture.

Sentence 1:
Achievements and Recognition
Dr. Wai-Ting Lam, who recently obtained a PhD in Mathematics from Yeshiva University, has been honored with a prestigious NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship (MPS-ASCEND) from the National Science Foundation.
Sentence 2:
Podcast
Professor Edward Belbruno recently appeared on the People Behind the Science podcast to discuss his research on studying the movement of objects in space and finding efficient paths to the Moon and Mars.

Sentence 1:
Bestseller Book
"The Fractional Laplacian," written by Prof. Wenxiong Chen in collaboration with Yan Li and Pei Ma, has been recognized as one of the top 10 best-selling mathematics books of 2020.
Sentence 2:
REU (Research Experiences for Undergraduates)
Computational Dynamics and Topology
Yeshiva University will be hosting an REU program in Computational Dynamics and Topology in the summer of 2023.

Sentence 2:
Capstone/Internship at Standard and Poor's Global
Students will have the opportunity to participate in a capstone/internship program at Standard and Poor's Global, focusing on smart tagging and extracting credit action signals from S&P Ratings Research Articles.

Sentence 1: The program will begin in June 2021, and interested individuals can contact Marian.Gidea@yu.edu for more information.
Sentence 2:

Sentence 1: The Media Studies minor provides students with the opportunity to delve into the interpretation, history, and artistic creation of various media forms, from traditional to modern.
Sentence 2: This includes print journalism, literature, film, television, and internet platforms.

Sentence 1: Through this program, students will explore the historical significance of media, its relationship to other cultural expressions, its changing societal influence, and develop skills in analyzing media content and its impact.
Sentence 2: The field of Media Studies incorporates elements from various disciplines such as English, History, Sociology, Marketing, and Computer Science.

Sentence 1: Students have the opportunity to select from a diverse range of electives that align with their individual interests and goals.
Sentence 2: Explore the courses available for electives and their prerequisites.

Sentence 1: The Philip and Sarah Belz Department of Music provides undergraduate students the chance to immerse themselves in the worlds of Western classical music and jazz through both coursework and performance opportunities.
Sentence 2: Regardless of their major, students are encouraged to join music ensembles and take courses in musical studies.

Sentence 1: In order to enroll in music history courses, students must first complete the prerequisite course, Sense of Music (MUS 1111A).
Sentence 2: It is important for students pursuing a minor in music to maintain a well-rounded education by balancing academic courses such as history, theory, and style analysis with performance courses like chamber ensembles, jazz ensemble, and applied music lessons.

Sentence 1: The study and enjoyment of music should complement each other.
Sentence 2: Similarly, music theory courses, such as harmony, prioritize the practice of composing music.

Sentence 1: The Music Department encourages its minors to enhance their performance skills by enrolling in at least one performance-oriented course each term during their time as students.
Sentence 2: As a result, many music minors exceed the required number of courses in music performance ensembles and lessons for their minor.

Sentence 1: Our music department is located on the second floor of the Schottenstein Center.
Sentence 2: The Recital Room features a beautiful Steinway grand piano, and we also have two baby grand pianos and five Baldwin upright pianos for students to practice on.

Sentence 1: On the second floor, there are four sound-proof practice booths where students can work until approximately 1 a.m. every day the building is open.
Sentence 2: The department also provides a MIDI Electronic Music Studio for students to use.

Sentence 1: Yeshiva University provides a variety of music ensemble opportunities for undergraduate students.
Sentence 2: The Philip and Sarah Belz Department of Music offers chamber music performance courses led by faculty members, as well as the Yeshiva University Jazz Ensemble under the direction of Dr. Bartholomew.

Sentence 1: The performance ensembles at Yeshiva College showcase their talents through public concerts held on campus every term.
Sentence 2: Students have the opportunity to participate in Chamber Music Ensembles, which are one-credit courses offered each term.

Sentence 1: Dr. Levy and Dr. Bartholomew coordinate chamber groups of different sizes and skill levels to practice and present classical music from various styles and periods.
Sentence 2: Any YU students who wish to participate in a chamber ensemble can contact Dr. Bartholomew for an audition at Schottenstein 213 or by calling 212.960.5353.

Sentence 1: Musicians who are interested should have the ability to read music.
Sentence 2: Rehearsals will be scheduled at a time that works for all members of each ensemble.

Sentence 1: The Yeshiva University Jazz Ensemble welcomes all YU students who are interested in participating in the course for one credit per term.
Sentence 2: Prospective members must audition with Dr. Bartholomew, the director of the Jazz Ensemble, in order to join.

Sentence 1: The Jazz Ensemble meets every Monday from 8:00 to 9:30 p.m.
Sentence 2: In the weeks leading up to concerts, they may have an additional rehearsal during the week.

Sentence 1: The Jazz Ensemble showcases their talents through two public concerts annually, featuring music exclusively composed or arranged by Dr. Levy or Dr. Bartholomew for over 25 years.
Sentence 2: Every piece has been customized to suit the Jazz Ensemble's yearly adjustments in instrumentation.

Sentence 1: For further details regarding the Music Department at Yeshiva College, kindly reach out to Professor Daniel Beliavsky at beliavsk@yu.edu or call 212.960.5400 ext.
Sentence 2: MUS 1111A The Sense of Music is a 2-credit course that satisfies the general humanities requirement in art or music.

Sentence 1: Students will explore the art of music through guided listening experiences to enhance their aural perception, historical understanding, awareness of music's formal processes, and ability to critically evaluate and appreciate music aesthetically.
Sentence 2: While a background in music is not necessary, students enrolled in MUS 1112A Inventing Music will explore the creative process of composing music.

Sentence 1: This course, worth 2 credits, satisfies the general humanities requirement in either art or music.
Sentence 2: This course is a unique take on the traditional introduction to music, with a strong emphasis on fostering creativity through composition.

Sentence 1: Students will explore the basics of music theory and language before diving into hands-on exercises and projects to create their own songs and musical pieces in smaller formats.
Sentence 2: No prior musical background is necessary to explore a wide range of musical genres and styles.

Sentence 1: MUS 1141 or 1141H explores the connection between texts and music, focusing on how sound can bring text to life.
Sentence 2: This 3-credit course delves into the symbiotic relationship between texts and music, highlighting the importance of interpretation.

Sentence 1: In MUS 1341, students will journey through the evolution of Western music from Antiquity through the Renaissance.
Sentence 2: This 2-credit course will explore the development of various forms and practices in music during these eras, with a special focus on the emergence of polyphony and secular art music.

Sentence 1: Students will study the works of prominent composers such as Dufay, Ockeghem, Josquin, and Monteverdi, gaining a deeper understanding of the musical landscape during this period.
Sentence 2: Prerequisite: MUS 1111 is required for enrollment in MUS 1350 - Music in the Baroque and Classical Eras.

Sentence 1: This course explores the evolution of triadic music, tonality, and musical forms from the Baroque period to the Classical era.
Sentence 2: Students will study the historical and cultural contexts that shaped these musical styles and gain a deeper understanding of the music of this time.

Sentence 1: This course explores the evolution of Western music from the Baroque era to the 20th century, focusing on key musical forms such as opera, concerto, fugue, sonata, and symphony.
Sentence 2: Beginning with the groundbreaking works of Beethoven and their lasting impact on future composers, students will examine the development of chromaticism and the breakdown of tonality in the Romantic era.

Sentence 1: The course also delves into the innovative harmonic and contrapuntal techniques of 20th-century music, tracing the evolution of Western music from Beethoven to contemporary composers like Adams.
Sentence 2: The courses MUS 1371 and MUS 1381 explore the rich history of American popular music, from the influence of radio and recording technologies to the social and political implications of music between 1865 and 1985.

Sentence 1: MUS 1371 focuses on Rhythm and Blues and Rock and Roll, while MUS 1381 delves into the History of Jazz, tracing the evolution of African, Afro-American, and Euro-American musical genres that merged into uniquely North American popular and art music in the 20th century.
Sentence 2: This course delves into various styles of Jazz music, such as traditional, swing, bebop, and modal and free jazz.

Sentence 1: The focus is on exploring recordings of influential and innovative performers from each era.
Sentence 2: By taking this class, students can fulfill the general humanities requirement in art or music.

Sentence 1: This genre course offers a deep dive into the world of music, using guided listening experiences to enhance aural perception, provide a historical context, and explore the formal techniques found in string quartets since Haydn's Op.
Participants will also gain critical skills for evaluating and appreciating music on an aesthetic level.
Sentence 2: While a background in music is not necessary, students can still enroll in the following courses: MUS 1661 Survey of Operatic Literature and MUS 1931, 1932 Musicology, each worth 3 credits.

Sentence 1: Additionally, there are seminars on special topics, typically offered every other year after discussions with interested students.

Sentence 1: Prerequisites for this course include Music 2112 and at least one course in music history (1341, 1350, 1351, or 1381).
Sentence 2:
Course Title: Diatonic Harmony (MUS 2111-2112)
Credits: 3 
This course explores the fundamental principles of tonal music, focusing on melodic construction, voice leading, harmony, and counterpoint.

Sentence 1: A prerequisite for this course is the ability to read music.
Sentence 2: Additionally, students must also enroll in an ear training laboratory (MUS 2111L-2112L), which will be determined by a placement exam at the start of the semester.

Sentence 1: MUS 2111L-2112L Ear Training I and II is a 1-credit laboratory course that focuses on helping students master the skills taught in Diatonic Harmony.
Sentence 2: The course emphasizes the development of relative pitch memory and the recognition of intervals, chords, and chord inversions.

Sentence 1: In MUS 2111, students will develop their sight-singing abilities by practicing with basic melodies and counterpoints, as well as honing their skills in chordal accompaniment on the keyboard.
Sentence 2: This course is a corequisite for MUS 2112.

Sentence 1:
Course Title: Chromatic Harmony I and II (MUS 2113, 2114)
Credit Hours: 3
Building upon the foundation of Diatonic Harmony, this course explores the principles of chromatic voice leading and harmony.
Sentence 2: The exploration of these topics is facilitated through the use of model composition and analysis.

Sentence 1: Additionally, in the second semester, students will be introduced to post-tonal theory and analysis.
Sentence 2: This course requires completion of MUS 2112.

Sentence 1: MUS 2113L and 2114L, Keyboard Skills I and II, offer 1 credit each.
Sentence 2: These courses provide piano instruction for adult beginners, focusing on practicing techniques to reach the level of Bach's Inventions and Clementi's Sonatinas.

Sentence 1: Advanced Theory and Composition (MUS 2127, 2128) is a seminar designed for students who have a strong foundation in music theory, musicology, or music composition.
Sentence 2: This course, worth 2-3 credits, explores topics such as MIDI studies and electric-acoustic techniques to further enhance students' understanding and skills in the field of music.

Sentence 1: This course, Musical Performance and Interpretation (MUS 3461-3469), requires completion of MUS 2112.
Sentence 2: It focuses on rehearsing and analyzing music from various composers to enhance performance skills, deepen understanding of musical styles, and develop a nuanced approach to musical interpretation.

Sentence 1: Explore the world of classical chamber music with courses MUS 3461-3466, featuring works by composers such as Bach, Schubert, and Brahms.
Sentence 2: Before enrolling, be sure to consult with the music adviser for guidance.

Sentence 1: For those interested in jazz, consider auditioning for the Jazz Ensemble courses MUS 3467-3469 under the instruction of the instructor.

Course Title: Applied Musical Studies (MUS 4111-4114)
Credit: 1 credit
Description: This course offers vocal or instrumental music lessons tailored by the music staff.

Sentence 1: The Sociology Department provides students with the opportunity to pursue a major or minor in sociology, along with the option to minor in public health.
Sentence 2: A degree in sociology equips students with valuable skills for furthering their education in graduate studies or pursuing a career in a variety of fields such as law, criminal justice, social work, research, public administration, business, medicine, counseling, health care management, or other service professions.

Sentence 1: Sociology is a field of study that examines the complexities of social life, including the dynamics of social change and the underlying causes and effects of human behavior.
Sentence 2: Sociologists study the relationships and interactions within groups, organizations, and societies to understand the structure and dynamics at play.

Sentence 1: The scope of sociology is vast, encompassing everything from personal relationships within families to group dynamics in larger communities.
Sentence 2: This includes examining various aspects such as organized crime, religious cults, social divides based on race, gender, and class, as well as shared cultural beliefs.

Sentence 1: Additionally, sociologists also delve into the sociology of work and sports to gain insights into how individuals function within these specific contexts.
Sentence 2: Sociology is a dynamic field with vast scope and significance in research, theory, and practical applications.

Sentence 1: It tackles complex societal issues of our time, making it a rapidly growing discipline that is increasingly utilized by policymakers and program developers.
Sentence 2: The Sociology Department at Yeshiva College is dedicated to equipping students with a deep understanding of social inequality, behavioral patterns, mechanisms for social change and resistance, and the functioning of social systems.

Sentence 1: Our mission is to foster a rigorous and intellectually grounded exploration of the social and cultural landscape.
Sentence 2: The foundation of sociology lies in social and cultural theory, as well as the scientific method.

Sentence 1: Students in our sociology program have the chance to enhance their theoretical and analytical abilities, allowing them to effectively assess and conduct social research and analysis.
Sentence 2: The Department is dedicated to utilizing these tools to gain insight into and tackle social issues and disparities across various levels of society - from global to institutional, cultural to interpersonal.

Sentence 1: Students are also urged to delve into their own role within society and their connection to culture.
Sentence 2: The Department is committed to fostering sociological knowledge and skills that can be utilized in various environments, including both public and private sectors, as well as in the pursuit of further academic and professional achievements.

Sentence 1: Our goal is to prepare graduates to be active participants in a rapidly changing and diverse society.
Sentence 2: The program aims to equip sociology majors with the ability to understand and analyze sociological concepts and theories, as well as apply research methods to explore sociological topics and questions effectively.

Sentence 1: Occupational Therapy Doctorate program prepares students to become occupational therapists who play a crucial role in helping individuals of all ages manage their daily activities, cope with illness or disability, and maintain their overall well-being.
Sentence 2: This program equips students with the necessary skills and knowledge to make a positive impact on people's lives.

Sentence 1: The Katz School's Occupational Therapy Doctorate program is the first of its kind in the New York metropolitan area, offering comprehensive training for compassionate and skilled professionals.
Sentence 2: Students are equipped to provide holistic services by combining theory, research, and clinical skills.

Sentence 1: Graduates of this program will become lifelong learners, leaders, and advocates for the field of occupational therapy in various communities around the world.
Sentence 2: In cutting-edge labs, expert faculty will guide you in utilizing your acquired knowledge to develop crucial skills for promoting health, well-being, and resilience through occupational engagement.

Sentence 1: The need for skilled occupational therapists is on the rise.
Sentence 2: By completing YU's hands-on, entry-level Occupational Therapy Doctorate program in less than three years, you will acquire the skills needed to assist clients in achieving greater independence and confidence in daily activities.

Sentence 1: Our program offers a range of highlights, including hands-on experience in fully equipped OT labs, a focus on occupation-based practice and community health, and the development of critical thinking and clinical reasoning skills.
Sentence 2: Students will also have the opportunity to engage in inter-professional learning and build relationships with top clinical directors in fieldwork placements.

Sentence 1: Our program mission aligns with the AOTA Vision 2025, aiming to maximize health, well-being, and quality of life for all individuals through effective solutions that promote participation in everyday living.
Sentence 2: The goal of the YU Occupational Therapy Doctorate program is to equip students with the knowledge and skills needed to become compassionate and skilled scholar-practitioners.

Sentence 1: Our program focuses on providing inclusive, equitable, and evidence-based services by integrating theory, research, and practical knowledge, along with clinical expertise.
Sentence 2: Through student-centered teaching methods, thematic program elements, and key curriculum components such as critical thinking and clinical reasoning, we aim to prepare students to excel as reflective and competent scholar-practitioners.

Sentence 1: Additionally, our program emphasizes the development of self-awareness, professional identity, and cultural competency to ensure students are well-rounded and effective in their practice.
Sentence 2: Our scholar-practitioners are committed to continuous learning and serving as advocates and leaders in their profession, as well as in diverse local and global communities.

Sentence 1: Working in advanced laboratories with faculty, our students gain practical experience applying theoretical knowledge and developing skills to enhance health, well-being, and resilience through meaningful occupational engagement.
Sentence 2: The philosophy of the Occupational Therapy Doctorate program at the Katz School in New York City is aligned with the mission statement and values of Yeshiva University, as well as the principles of the occupational therapy profession and the professional values of the program's faculty.

Sentence 1: The program emphasizes the importance of health, well-being, occupation, and community, and encourages collaboration among faculty, students, and the community to integrate science, health, and technology in their practice for the betterment of patients and society.
Sentence 2: Yeshiva University's Occupational Therapy Doctorate program has received full accreditation from the Accreditation Council for Occupational Therapy Education (ACOTE) of the American Occupational Therapy Association (AOTA).

Sentence 1: This accreditation ensures that the program meets high standards of quality and excellence in occupational therapy education.
Sentence 2: Graduates of the program are eligible to take the national certification examination administered by the National Board for Certification in Occupational Therapy (NBCOT), allowing them to become licensed occupational therapists.

Sentence 1: Upon passing the NBCOT certification examination, an individual will be granted the title of Occupational Therapist, Registered (OTR).
Sentence 2: Most states require this certification in order to practice occupational therapy.

Sentence 1: Having a felony conviction could impact a graduate's chances of taking the NBCOT certification exam and obtaining state licensure.
Sentence 2: If you have any questions, please contact ACOTE at www.acoteonline.org or AOTA at 301-652-6611.

Sentence 1: For more information, you can contact the National Board for Certification in Occupational Therapy (NBCOT) at www.nbcot.org.
Sentence 2: After completing the Occupational Therapy Doctorate program, students will have the ability to create and execute client-centered care plans that take into account cultural values, beliefs, and individual needs.

Sentence 1: Utilize strong communication skills to collaborate effectively within a diverse healthcare team.
Sentence 2: Engage in critical analysis of evidence in occupational therapy practice to contribute to the advancement of the profession through scholarly research and dissemination.

Sentence 1: Develop interventions that prioritize occupation as both the method and goal of the therapeutic process, in alignment with the core principles of the profession.
Sentence 2: Implement these interventions effectively to ensure meaningful outcomes for clients.

Sentence 1: Incorporate health promotion and wellness strategies into interventions for individuals, communities, and populations.
Sentence 2: Serve as a role model and advocate for occupational therapy across all service areas.

Sentence 1: Upon graduating from the Occupational Therapy Doctorate program, students can take the national certification exam offered by the National Board for Certification in Occupational Therapy (NBCOT) to become a licensed occupational therapist.
Sentence 2: Once they pass the exam, they will be officially recognized as a registered occupational therapist (OTR).

Sentence 1: In order to practice occupational therapy, most states require individuals to obtain a license, which is typically dependent on passing the NBCOT certification exam.
Sentence 2: It is important to be aware that individuals with a felony conviction or prior criminal record may be ineligible to take the NBCOT exam, obtain a state license, and ultimately practice in the field.

Sentence 1: In order to apply for the exam, you will be required to answer questions about felonies and convictions.
Sentence 2: Before beginning your Occupational Therapy Doctorate studies, please reach out to NBCOT for further information.

Sentence 1: You can find information on the NBCOT certification pass rate, graduation rates, and employment data for the program on the NBCOT website.

Sentence 2: The field of math occupations is projected to experience a significant 27 percent growth by the year 2029, surpassing the average growth rate for all occupations.

Sentence 1: Current research areas include the dynamics of systems with small degrees of freedom focusing on ergodicity, chaotic behavior, and statistical properties, as well as the dynamics of systems with large and infinite degrees of freedom emphasizing statistical and thermodynamic properties.
Sentence 2: Research also encompasses the dynamics of celestial bodies, financial markets, and climate, as well as applied noncommutative geometry and materials science, applied operator algebras and dynamical systems, differential geometry and partial differential equations, and topological data analysis.

Sentence 1: Additionally, research includes quantum algorithms for quantum computers.
Sentence 2: Join our diverse community of Math Fellows, consisting of students and alumni from over 30 countries, to collaborate on cutting-edge research, citywide initiatives, and new technologies that contribute to a smarter, safer, and healthier world.

Sentence 1: As a Math Fellow, you will receive industry mentorship, have the opportunity to showcase and publish your research at our annual Symposium on Science, Technology, and Health, and receive a generous tuition scholarship.
Sentence 2: Learn more about the Fellows Program and how you can be a part of this exciting research community.

Sentence 1: YU undergraduates have the opportunity to pursue a Pathways Option, allowing them to earn up to 12 graduate credits that will count towards both their bachelor's and master's degrees.

Sentence 1: Requirements for admission: Applicants must be juniors in any undergraduate program with a GPA of at least 3.2 and a minimum grade of B+ in the specified prerequisite courses.
Sentence 2: Graduate courses may be taken by students starting in their junior or senior year.

Sentence 1: In order to enroll in graduate coursework, students must have completed Calculus I and II, Multivariable Calculus, and Linear Algebra, all with a minimum grade of B-plus.

The PhD program in mathematics at Yeshiva University focuses on the study of complex systems in various forms such as financial markets, biological systems, quantum materials, meta-materials, fluids, plasmas, networks, and big data.
Sentence 2: The faculty in the department utilize a range of analytical tools including topological, geometrical, and functional analysis, optimization theory, complexity theory, partial differential equations, noncommutative geometry, operator algebras, risk theory, and ergodic theory.

The Ph.D. program offers three tracks tailored to the individual needs of students: 

- Track I: A three-year program designed for students with 60 credits of graduate coursework 
- Track II: A four-year program suitable for students with 30 credits of graduate coursework 
- Track III: A five-year program for students with no previous graduate coursework 
Earning a Ph.D. in mathematics opens up a wide range of career opportunities in fields such as materials science, dynamical systems, and complex systems.
