Program Overview
Our Ph.D. program in New York City offers a 66-credit doctorate, with 36 credits beyond a master's degree.

Sentence 1: Students have the flexibility to enroll on a full-time or part-time basis, with evening courses designed to accommodate those who work full-time.
Sentence 2: Our program boasts nationally and internationally recognized faculty who provide mentorship to students working on research projects.

Sentence 1:
in Mathematics from Yeshiva University:

Sentence 2: In the first year of the Mathematics program, students will take 15 credits per semester of course work towards their Master of Arts degree.

Sentence 1: They will also take the Basic Qualifying Examination to earn the Master of Arts degree.
Sentence 2: In the second year, students will focus on special topics with 9 credits per semester.

Sentence 1: They will also take the Advanced Qualifying Examination.
Sentence 2: In the third, fourth, and fifth years, students will take MAT 705 for six semesters as part of their PhD in Mathematical Sciences program.

Sentence 1: Most courses will be 3 credits, unless otherwise specified.
Sentence 2: Except for Topics courses and Problem seminars, the initial semester of a two-semester course will provide an overview of key concepts within the course.

Sentence 1: The second semester, which will only be offered if there is enough interest from students, will involve a more in-depth exploration of the topics introduced in the first semester.
Sentence 2: This course, MAT 5115, covers fundamental concepts in number theory such as divisibility, congruence, quadratic reciprocity, quadratic forms, diophantine equations, and rational approximation of irrationals.

Sentence 1: These concepts have practical applications in cryptology and data security.
Sentence 2:
Course Title: Advanced Linear Algebra (MAT 5117)

This course explores fundamental concepts in linear algebra, including vector spaces, bases, dimensions, direct sums, and factor spaces.

Sentence 1: It also covers topics such as linear transformations, functionals, dual spaces, matrices, determinants, and systems of linear equations.
Sentence 2: Additionally, students will learn about diagonalization, normal and canonical forms, elementary divisors, bilinear and quadratic forms, inner products, Euclidean and unitary spaces, orthogonal and symmetric matrices, as well as tensors and exterior algebra.

Sentence 1: The course also delves into practical applications of linear algebra, such as in Markov chains and linear regression analysis.
Sentence 2: This course introduces students to analytic methods that are important for practical applications, as well as the mathematical foundations, contexts, and limitations of these methods.

Sentence 1: Topics covered include functions of a complex variable, integration, and differentiation in the complex domain.
Sentence 2: The study of Cauchy's Theorem, the Cauchy Integral Formula, Laurent expansion, and residues are fundamental to understanding complex analysis.

Sentence 1: Additionally, exploring the elements of conformal mapping, special functions, and series and product representations provide further insight into the intricate nature of mathematical analysis.
Sentence 2: In the Problem Seminar courses MAT 5200 and 5201, students will learn how to apply their mathematical knowledge to solve specific problems in industrial and technological settings.

Sentence 1: This includes areas such as operations management, risk theory, shock wave theory, atomic force microscopy, and materials science.
Sentence 2: In the Ordinary Differential Equations course MAT 5209, students will study differential and integral equations in the real domain.

Sentence 1: Topics covered include existence and stability theory, the Sturm-Liouville problem for linear equations, and techniques for solving equations in special classes.
Sentence 2: Exploring differential and integral equations in the complex domain, including equations of Fuchsian type and special functions, along with transform methods.

Sentence 1: Investigating the shift towards chaos in dynamic systems.
Sentence 2: This course, consisting of MAT 5210, 5211, and 5215, delves into the theory of second-order partial differential equations.

Sentence 1: Topics covered include the Cauchy problem, boundary value problems related to potential theory, and variational principles.
Sentence 2: Equations with diverse applications in finance, geometry, plasma physics, and gas dynamics.

Sentence 1: In Functional Analysis I and II (MAT 5230, 5231), students will study Banach and Hilbert spaces, linear functionals, the Hahn-Banach theorem, dual spaces, linear operators, the closed graph theorem, Riesz theory for compact operators, and spectral theory.
Sentence 2: In the Algebra course (MAT 5253), students will explore sets, Boolean algebra, and cardinal numbers.

Sentence 1: The study of abstract algebra includes topics such as groups, rings, ideals, integral domains, fields, algebraic number fields, and Galois theory.
Sentence 2: These concepts have diverse applications in various fields including computer science and combinatorics.

Sentence 1:
Course Title: Probability Theory and Risk Measures
Course Codes: MAT 5256, 5257
This course explores the concepts of probability theory and risk measures, examining their applications in financial decision-making, operations management, and the theory of gambling.
Sentence 2: Exploring various stochastic processes such as random walks, Brownian motion, fractional Brownian motion, white noise processes, Markov chains, and Markov processes, as well as time series analysis and convexity methods.

Sentence 1: Additionally, studying nonperiodic cycles and processes that exhibit memory effects.
Sentence 2:
Exploring Concepts in Geometry
Course: MAT 5258
Studying synthetic geometry and projective spaces.

Sentence 1: Algebraic geometry plays a crucial role in various practical applications, including computer graphics, finite-element analysis, geometrical optics, and the study of caustics.
Sentence 2: This course explores Differential and Riemannian Geometry, focusing on the classical differential geometry of curves and surfaces in space.

Sentence 1: Topics include intrinsic geometry on a surface.
Sentence 2: Exploring tensor calculus in relation to geometry in multiple dimensions, with a focus on applications such as harmonic maps in geometric analysis.

Sentence 1: Exploring the concepts of Lie groups and Lie algebras, as well as vector bundles and connections, within the context of special and general relativity.
Sentence 2: This course delves into modern differential geometry to provide a deeper understanding of these topics.

Sentence 1: Exploring Morse theory and delving into the fundamentals of Hodge theory.
Sentence 2: This course covers applications of high-energy physics and gauge-field theory, as well as topics in Topology I and Topology II (MAT 5262 and 5263).

Sentence 1: It provides a thorough introduction to point-set topology, differential topology, homotopy, and homology.
Sentence 2: In MAT 5265, we explore the fundamental concepts of real analysis and their applications, focusing on the Lebesgue measure and integral for functions of a real variable.

Sentence 1: Calculating integrals over sigma algebras and understanding probability measures.
Sentence 2: This course will provide an overview of Hilbert spaces and LP-spaces, along with their applications in Fourier series and transforms.

Sentence 1: By exploring these concepts, students will gain a deeper understanding of their significance in various mathematical processes.
Sentence 2: MAT 5266 Mathematical Statistics focuses on the development of statistical models based on probability theorems and covers topics related to statistics and data analysis in a rigorous manner.

Sentence 1: MAT 5267 Convex Optimization delves into convex analysis in finite dimensions, linear programming, and convex optimization with constraints.
Sentence 2: It also explores vector optimization problems from both theoretical and computational viewpoints.

Sentence 1: This course introduces the statistical and computational fundamentals that underpin modern data science applications in fields such as finance, economics, biomedical science, and other related disciplines.
Sentence 2: Topics covered include convex risk measures, portfolio optimization, utility maximization problems, and the use of big data in various industries.

Sentence 1: The key elements of this course involve delving into data, creating models, utilizing data mining technologies, and applying these concepts through real-world examples.
Sentence 2: Students will also have the opportunity to enhance their learning through practical programming exercises using the iPython programming environment, providing them with a hands-on understanding of data science analytics.

Sentence 1:
Exploring Data Science in Various Fields: A Study of Biomedical, Financial, Geoscience, and Astronomical Applications
MAT 5272
Analyzing top data science research in the fields of biomedical science, quantitative finance, geoscience, and astronomical sciences.
Sentence 2:
Analytical Problem Solving and Estimation Techniques
MAT 5301, 5302
Learning problem-solving strategies and estimation methods in both real and complex analysis.

Sentence 1: This article provides an overview of practical analysis methods, focusing on their application in real-world scenarios rather than theoretical frameworks.
Sentence 2: It highlights the importance of using these methods in the fields of finance and engineering.

Sentence 1:
Course Title: Topics in Partial Differential Equations I, II
Course Code: MAT 5310, 5311
This course covers the fundamental theory of linear partial differential equations, as well as semilinear, quasilinear, and fully nonlinear equations.
Sentence 2: Students will learn about the various types of differential equations and their applications in different fields.

Sentence 1: Topics covered in this course include variational theory, Cauchy and boundary value problems, as well as estimates and regularity of solutions.
Sentence 2: In this course, we will explore a variety of topics that have practical applications in geometry, finance, continuum mechanics, plasma physics, and engineering.

Sentence 1: Specifically, we will delve into Boolean logics, truth functions, quantification theory, and Turing machines as they relate to mathematical logic and computability theory.
Sentence 2: Exploring the intersection of horn algebras, lattices, and quasivarities in computer science, with a specific focus on their applications in artificial intelligence.

MAT 5317: Linear/Modern Algebra Readings

Sentence 1: In MAT 5320, students will study nonlinear and fractal time series, computational methods, and applications in areas such as econophysics, fractal statistics, and neural physics.
Sentence 2: In MAT 5330 and 5331, students will explore topics in functional analysis including Hilbert and Banach spaces, and operator theory.

Sentence 2: Yeshiva University's Graduate Program in Mathematical Sciences requires students to pass a qualifying examination in three key areas: Real Analysis, Complex Analysis, and a chosen Research Area.

Sentence 1: The examination will test students on a range of topics in Real Analysis and Complex Analysis, as well as provide sample exercises to help prepare them for success.
Sentence 2: The exercises on the exam will be different from the sample exercises provided.

Sentence 1: It is important to be able to solve a variety of exercises in order to adequately prepare for the exam.
Sentence 2: The third area of the exam focuses on the research subject that the student plans to pursue.

Sentence 1: This topic should be chosen in collaboration with the student's adviser.
Sentence 2: Before taking the qualifying examination, the student should ask their faculty adviser for a list of research topics and a bibliography to study.

Sentence 1: This oral exam is typically conducted by the candidate's advisory committee.
Sentence 2: The first two areas are typically tested together, while the third area is tested separately.

Sentence 1: Students can receive either a Pass or Fail grade on the exam.
Sentence 2: Students are allowed to retake the qualifying examination once.

Sentence 1: However, failing the exam a second time will lead to dismissal from the program.

Sentence 1: To secure on-campus housing for the upcoming academic year (2023-2024), kindly sign in to the Yeshiva University Housing Portal using your YU username and password.

Sentence 1: Please be aware that the deadline for housing applications was on Tuesday, May 16, 2023.
Sentence 2:
Mandatory University Housing for New Students

All incoming students are required to live in university housing for their first two semesters on campus.

Sentence 1: This policy aims to foster connections within the YU community and provide access to important campus resources for new students.
Sentence 2: If you choose not to live in university housing after your first two semesters, please be mindful when choosing your apartment and roommates.

Sentence 1: The university will not oversee or be liable for any non-university housing arrangements.
Sentence 2:
In order to be eligible for university housing on the Wilf Campus, you must meet one of the following criteria:

- Enrolled in one of the Jewish studies divisions and taking at least 12 credits per semester at Yeshiva College or Sy Syms School of Business.

Sentence 1: - A full-time student at the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS).
Sentence 2: Students pursuing semicha can reside in University Housing for the duration of their four-year residency at RIETS.

Sentence 1: Summer semesters will not be included in this eligibility period.
Sentence 2: Commit to following Jewish law and values, using common sense, good judgment, and courtesy in all your actions.

Sentence 1:
Yeshiva University welcomes you to explore our four campuses located in New York City, spanning across two boroughs:

- Wilf Campus: 500 West 185th Street, Manhattan
- Beren Campus: 245 Lexington Avenue, Manhattan
- Brookdale Center: 55 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan
- Resnick Campus: 1300 Morris Park Avenue and 1165 Morris Park Avenue, Bronx

Each campus offers a variety of amenities including residence halls, dining options, athletic facilities, and extracurricular activities.
Sentence 2: Additionally, students have access to our four-campus library system, which features a diverse collection of resources and services enhanced by modern technology.

Sentence 1: We invite you to immerse yourself in the vibrant academic and social community at Yeshiva University.
Sentence 2: YU Manhattan is situated in Washington Heights, a vibrant and historic neighborhood near the northern tip of Manhattan.

Sentence 2: Dr. Honggang Wang has been selected as the inaugural chair of the Computer Science Department at the Katz School.

Sentence 1: Dr. Wang, an accomplished computer scientist with a focus on AI, 5G/6G communications, and cybersecurity, has been appointed as the head of the Computer Science Department.
Sentence 2: With a wealth of knowledge in wireless health, wearable technology, autonomous vehicles, and communications, Dr. Wang is also recognized as an IEEE Fellow and Distinguished Lecturer.

Sentence 1: Dr. Wang has secured over $5 million in research grants from prestigious organizations such as the NSF, NIH, and U.S. Department of Transportation.
Sentence 2: Dr. Paul Russo, the dean of the Katz School, lauds Dr. Wang as an outstanding researcher who will provide leadership to the Computer Science Department.

Sentence 1: At the University of Massachusetts-Dartmouth, Dr. Wang's research in IoT centered around developing a portable "intensive care unit" and autonomous vehicle navigation algorithms.
Sentence 2: His work also involves creating a wearable biosensor system that can remotely monitor infants to anticipate and prevent life-threatening events such as Sudden Infant Death Syndrome.

Sentence 1: Dr. Wang's extensive knowledge and skills make him a valuable addition to the Katz School's faculty, particularly in the fields of wireless health and cybersecurity.
Sentence 2: His expertise in communication and autonomous vehicles will greatly enhance the new Computer Science Department.

Sentence 1: Dr. Wang, a highly accomplished computer engineer with a Ph.D., obtained his degrees from the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and Southwest Jiaotong University in Chengdu, China.
Sentence 2: He has been recognized for his outstanding research and leadership in IEEE committees, earning an Outstanding Researcher Award from the IEEE Communications Society.

Sentence 1: Dr. Honggang Wang, a renowned leader in the field of computer science, has made significant contributions to the IEEE's Internet of Things Journal as editor-in-chief and has authored the book "Wireless Health."
Sentence 2: His appointment at the Katz School holds great importance.

Sentence 1: Dr. Wang's exceptional contributions in wireless health, autonomous vehicles, and cybersecurity have been acknowledged by the Katz School as he assumes the position of founding chair.
Sentence 2: Prior to this role, Dr. Wang's expertise in Internet of Things research was honed during his tenure as a senior faculty member at the University of Massachusetts-Dartmouth.

Sentence 1: Dr. Wang's innovative research involves creating a wireless body area network that monitors infant physiology from a distance to prevent serious health crises.
Sentence 2: He is also skilled in developing algorithms that improve autonomous vehicle navigation for safer transportation.

Sentence 1: Dr. Honggang Wang's leadership is propelling the Computer Science Department at the Katz School towards success.
Sentence 2: With his expertise in computer engineering and vast experience, Dr. Wang is equipped to elevate the department to unprecedented levels of achievement.

Sentence 2: Yeshiva University's record-breaking enrollment numbers are a significant milestone for the institution, especially considering the current national trend of declining college enrollment.
